creator: sjohnson@schwing.com
text:
Our internal network was upgraded to Windows Server 2003 ADS.  The application 
server where the Apache web server resides is still running Windows NT4 in a 
DMZ.  We cannot authenticate for file access to the internal network.  We can 
through windows explorer but not when going through the Apache web server.  We 
have internal network drives mapped on the application server and an ALIAS 
defined in the httpd.conf file.  The error we get is:  HTTP 404 The Page Cannot 
Be Found.  The entry in the httpd.conf file looks like:

Alias /whitebear/ "J:\/"

where J:\ is a file server in our internal network.  J:\ was upgraded to Server 
2003.

A blocker bug blocks the next release, not your scenario.  Changed priority.

Your syntax was wrong, the alias should point to either "J:/" or "//mach/share/"

You will probably have to change the "Logon as" or "Run as" service property
tab to an account with appropriate permissions.  That -user- must have a J: drive
map, but I really recommend the //mach/share/ falvor instead.

Apache 1.3/Win32 issues are no longer receiving any attention, Apache 2.2 is
current, upgrade already.  For that matter, upgrade your webserver's OS if you
can't get them to interoperate nicely.  That's not the Apache project's concern.

Finally post these sorts of problems to the peer user support lists, bugzilla
is for bugs in ASF software, not user configuration questions.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
Thank you for your very fast response, Will.  We have tried many things.  The 
syntax of the alias worked without problem prior to the upgrade to Windows 
Server 2003 ADS.  We have also tried using //machine/share/ syntax but that 
didn't work, either.  We have also used an administrator account in the "Run 
As" property.  Still didn't work.  Is there something else I can try?

Finally, I am not sure what a peer support list is.  Our only experience with 
Apache is that it came with our installation of Oracle Application Server 
9iAS.  They are not supporting the Apache Web Server.  I apologize if I am not 
posting this issue to the correct place.  I just don't know any better.

Thanks a lot!
Stuart Johnson
creator: sjohnson@schwing.com

text:
By 'peer support list', Will means the user mailing list. There's information
about it on the following page:  http://httpd.apache.org/lists.html#http-users

The cool part about a user mailing list (which is the peer part in Will's reply)
is that the people on there are other users (as well as some of the developers)
and the economies of scale mean there's a much higher chance that another user
will have the answer for you.
